required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Use of Ultrasonic Bone Scalpel in Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis
clinical_study.official_title: Use of Ultrasonic Bone Scalpel in Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis - Randomized Clinical Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The primary purpose of this randomized trial is to compare the efficacy of an ultrasonic bone scalpel (or osteotome device) with standard of care surgical instruments during posterior spine fusion with instrumentation.

primary_outcome.description: Estimated blood loss is being obtained from the report generated by the cell saver.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Patients With Intraoperative and Postoperative Blood Transfusions in the Ultrasonic Bone Scalpel Group and Standard of Care Group
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Intraoperative, Short Term Postoperative (end of procedure until hospital discharge, up to 7 days after surgery)
secondary_outcome.description: This outcome measure measures the number of patients with intraoperative and postoperative blood transfusions placed in the Ultrasonic Bone Scalpel Group and the Standard of Care Group.

other_outcome.time_frame: Preoperative (up to 1 month before scheduled date of surgery)
Short Term Postoperative (3 month), Long Term Postoperative (1 year)
other_outcome.description: Cobb angle is a measurement of the degree of side-to-side spinal curvature used to define Scoliosis. A Cobb angle of 10 degrees is the minimum angle to define scoliosis. Angles of 40-50 degrees or more may require corrective surgery. Cobb angle will be measured from postoperative radiographs

other_outcome.measure: Percent of Participants With Lenke 1 Curve Pattern
other_outcome.time_frame: Preoperative (up to 1 month before scheduled date of surgery)
other_outcome.description: Lenke Type 1 is a main thoracic curve pattern, and is the most common pattern observed in cases of adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (AIS). The Lenke Classification System provides surgeons with a simple, accurate, and reproducible way to communicate about scoliosis. It relies on measurements taken from standard x-rays. The surgeon evaluates the x-ray from the front, side, and in bending positions. Each scoliosis curve is then classified in three ways: by the curve type based on the three regions of the spine, a lumbar spine modifier, and a sagittal thoracic modifier. The classification system combines the curve type (1-6) with the lumbar modifier (A, B, C) and the sagittal thoracic modifier (-. N, +) to form the complete classification.

other_outcome.time_frame: Short Term Postoperative (12-18 hours after procedure)

arm_group.description: Surgeons will use the ultrasonic bone scalpel, to their discretion, along with standard of care manual devices when performing the posterior spinal fusion.
Surgeons will use, to their discretion, only standard of care manual devices when performing the posterior spinal fusion.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. 10-18 years of age
2. Diagnosis of Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis (AIS)
3. Scheduled for a posterior spinal fusion (without Schwab Grade II or higher osteotomy)
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Plan for a posterior column osteotomy of Schwab Grade II or higher
2. Prior spinal surgery
3. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) abnormalities (such as syrinx and/or chiari malformations)
4. Subjects with medical comorbidities (e.g. heart, lung, kidney disease)
5. Subjects with bleeding diatheses
6. Non-idiopathic etiology for scoliosis

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

group.title: Ultrasonic Bone Scalpel Group
group.description: Surgeons will use the ultrasonic bone scalpel, to their discretion, along with standard of care manual devices when performing the posterior spinal fusion. Posterior Spinal Fusion Ultrasonic Bone Scalpel

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcome.title: Estimated Blood Loss/Level
outcome.description: Estimated blood loss is being obtained from the report generated by the cell saver.
outcome.population: The above 65 patients were analyzed as part of a treated cohort and an intention-to-treat cohort. The discrepancy between the 65 patients with data evaluated and the 66 patients initially consented is explained by 1 patient who withdrew consent from the study. The study team therefore did not feel it was ethical to collect this patient's data.

outcome.description: Lenke Type 1 is a main thoracic curve pattern, and is the most common pattern observed in cases of adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (AIS). The Lenke Classification System provides surgeons with a simple, accurate, and reproducible way to communicate about scoliosis. It relies on measurements taken from standard x-rays. The surgeon evaluates the x-ray from the front, side, and in bending positions. Each scoliosis curve is then classified in three ways: by the curve type based on the three regions of the spine, a lumbar spine modifier, and a sagittal thoracic modifier. The classification system combines the curve type (1-6) with the lumbar modifier (A, B, C) and the sagittal thoracic modifier (-. N, +) to form the complete classification.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
